author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Coronavirus, Germany, N.H.S.: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Wait … What’s Getting You Through?
description: Even a screen saver can help right now.
content: We spend a lot of our days chatting with each other about things we see online, trying to make sense of it all. This week in the Styles newsletter, Wait …, the team is sharing some things that are getting us through these times. Hope you’re hanging in there! If you want to share something that is helping you, email wait@nytimes.com. We may publish some of them in the coming weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Uber’s Bid for Grubhub Shows That Deals Aren’t Dead Yet
description: Mergers are taking a hit during the pandemic, but there’s still an appetite for certain types of transactions.
content: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Alexander
title: Jason Alexander: Jerry Stiller Was Wonderful, Always
description: There was something about him that was relatable and lovable and it shone in everything he had ever done.
content: I was standing on the “Seinfeld” stage, and I had a small conundrum: Could I get Jerry Stiller to smack me in the head?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Isay
title: Now Is the Time to Ask Your Loved Ones About Their Lives
description: I’ve spent years collecting intimate interviews. Take it from me: A conversation about life’s big questions is the very definition of time well spent.
content: Today we are faced with a pandemic that plays to our worst, most basic human fears: uncertainty, mortality, loneliness. Perhaps most devastating of all is the combination of all three — the terrifying prospect that we might die alone, without the embrace of a loved one, with words left unsaid. These feelings and fears are palpable for all of us: first-time parents, bored college students, furloughed workers and, perhaps especially, aging retirees who are uniquely vulnerable to Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 2 Art Gallery Shows to Explore From Home
description: Galleries and museums are getting creative about presenting work online during the coronavirus crisis. Here are two shows worth viewing virtually.
content: James Luna inaugurated his piece “Take a Picture With a Real Indian” in downtown New York nearly 30 years ago. As the title suggests, Luna, a member of California’s Luiseño tribe, simply offered himself to passers-by for souvenir photos. Later he would repeat the performance in a Washington Metro station, and in galleries, sometimes dressing for the occasion in “Indian” outfits, sometimes not, and always getting plenty of takers. The current show at Garth Greenan includes video and photography of these performances, a few life-size cardboard cutouts of Luna, and a handful of other works.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: On Politics: Fauci Speaks. Is the Government Listening?
description: A dire virus warning, and new wrangling over Trump’s tax returns: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: Voters waited in line at a polling place in a parking lot in Palmdale, Calif., where a House special election was being held.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $2.2 Million
description: A midcentury-modern house in Pasadena, Calif.; a rowhouse in Washington; and a triplex apartment in Brooklyn, N.Y.
content: A midcentury-modern house in Pasadena, Calif.; a rowhouse in Washington; and a triplex apartment in Brooklyn, N.Y.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Fauci Doesn’t Want to Bring America Off the Bench, Trevor Noah Says
description: The “Daily Show” host likened reopening the country too soon to an athlete coming back early from an injury: “Now you’re just a gym teacher telling fifth-graders about how you could have gone pro.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan O'Callaghan
title: This NASA Mission May Cause an Artificial Meteor Shower
description: A study says the DART mission’s collision with an asteroid near Earth may liberate enough debris to reach Earth’s atmosphere.
content: If all goes to plan, in September 2022 a NASA spacecraft, the Double Asteroid Redirection Test mission or DART, will slam into a space rock with the equivalent energy of three tons of TNT. The goal is to nudge the orbit of its target object ever-so-slightly, a practice run to see if we could divert an asteroid from a catastrophic impact with our planet in the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Where Is My Driverless Car?
description: The technology is tricky, and driverless cars may never fix all the problems we hoped they would.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Teenage Drivers
description: Nearly 20,000 Georgia teens were recently issued driver’s licenses without a road test. What do you think of that decision?
content: Last month, Georgia waived its road-test requirement for most drivers in an effort to help fight the spread of the coronavirus. In early May, the state said it had issued driver’s licenses to thousands of teenagers without one. Wisconsin is doing something similar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Watch These Rover Models Wiggle Out of Alien Sand Traps
description: A choreography of swimming, walking and rolling could help future rovers avoid getting stuck in loose soil on the moon or Mars.
content: Driving up a sandy hill on a distant world is a good way to get stuck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel L. Harris and Lisa Tarchak
title: ‘I Have Given Up’: Parenting in Quarantine
description: Readers tell us how they’re managing the Parent-Employee-Teacher trifecta during the pandemic.
content: What does parenting burnout look like during a pandemic? After a column by Farhad Manjoo on the subject, thousands of readers told us about their “new normal.” For many, excessive screen time was the least of their worries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nadja Popovich and Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Tracking the Environmental Rules Reversed Under Trump
description: Also this week, our reporter’s kitchen secrets revealed
content: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter! The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.  And, if you want to know what else we’re up to, you can follow the New York Times climate team on Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Dominus
title: The Voice of God. (And Knausgaard, Whitman, Machiavelli … )
description: How Edoardo Ballerini became the audiobook world’s most reliable narrator.
content: How Edoardo Ballerini became the audiobook world’s most reliable narrator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey
title: A Heartbreak for Children: When the County Fair Is Canceled
description: The coronavirus has thwarted summertime fairs, a tradition for youngsters who work on farms all year for their moment in the ring.
content: The stomach-flipping thrill of riding the Zipper on the midway. The funnel cakes with powdered sugar melting on the fried dough. The shave ice. The sweet, smelly medley of hay, dirt and manure drifting from the barn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek, Jim Tankersley and Emily Cochrane
title: Fed Chair Warns the Economy May Need More as Congress Hesitates
description: Jerome H. Powell pointed to potentially dire consequences if a lasting economic downturn is not averted with forceful policies.
content: The Federal Reserve chair, Jerome H. Powell, delivered a stark warning on Wednesday that the United States was experiencing an economic hit “without modern precedent,” one that could permanently damage the economy if Congress and the White House did not provide sufficient financial support to prevent a wave of bankruptcies and prolonged joblessness.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Murphy Hints N.J. Beaches May Open by Summer, With Limits
description: Gov. Murphy, in an interview with CNN, suggested that beaches would open by Memorial Day, subject to rules governing parks.
content: Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey suggested late Wednesday that the state’s popular beaches, a major tourist draw, would open in a limited way by Memorial Day, the traditional start of summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: Merkel Is ‘Outraged’ by Russian Hack but Struggling to Respond
description: Patience with President Vladimir Putin is running thin in Berlin. But Germany needs Russia’s help on several geopolitical fronts from Syria to Ukraine.
content: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel used strong words on Wednesday condemning an “outrageous” cyberattack by Russia’s foreign intelligence service on the German Parliament, her personal email account included. Russia, she said, was pursuing “a strategy of hybrid warfare.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabrielle Hamilton
title: A Bloody Mary Mix That Is as Good Virgin as It Is Spiked
description: Tomato juice doctored up with spices is a remarkable workhorse. I use it to brace myself for work or to unwind when I’m escaping.
content: When I was a kid, our family used to go to the West Amwell Fire Company chicken dinner every summer. It was advertised for weeks on a big letter-board sign planted in the cornfields along Route 179, and we passed it in the car with building excitement. On the June day, the firefighters rolled up the gates of the bays and set up long folding tables where the trucks were usually parked. The wives made cakes and the men worked immense charcoal fires walled in with cinder blocks and covered with metal grates where they basted the halved chickens by the hundred. You bought your ticket and stood in line, and when a spot opened up at one of the tables, you were seated. And there you ate a community supper, raising money for the volunteer fire company, flanked by what seemed to me a lot of old people and a lot of young parents while all the kids raced in and out, like hummingbirds docking for a few seconds at a juicy flower before zipping away again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: The Tiny Radio Stations That Lift Spirits in Hospitals
description: Volunteer-run broadcasters are a British tradition. During the pandemic, they’re cheering patients up with jazz standards and soft rock.
content: LONDON — Last Wednesday, Steve Coulby, a D.J. for Nottingham Hospitals Radio in England, read out a request from a patient battling Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: In a First, Renewable Energy Is Poised to Eclipse Coal in U.S.
description: The coronavirus has pushed the coal industry to once-unthinkable lows, and the consequences for climate change are big.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States is on track to produce more electricity this year from renewable power than from coal for the first time on record, new government projections show, a transformation partly driven by the coronavirus pandemic, with profound implications in the fight against climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Elon Musk Unleashed Again
description: The entrepreneur wants his businesses up and running now. Good luck trying to stop him.
content: How do you solve a problem like a tweet-storming Elon Musk?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Astead W. Herndon
title: In Bid for Party Unity, Biden Moves Beyond Restoring the Pre-Trump Era
description: Trying to win over progressives and aware that the coronavirus crisis is upending the political landscape, Joe Biden is increasingly using the language of systemic disruption.
content: Throughout the Democratic presidential primary, Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s rivals criticized his focus on restoring America to the pre-Trump era, accusing him of promoting a backward-looking political vision that ignored the deep-rooted causes of the nation’s problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek, Jim Tankersley and Emily Cochrane
title: Fed Chair Warns the Economy May Need More as Congress Hesitates
description: Jerome H. Powell pointed to potentially dire consequences if a lasting economic downturn is not averted with forceful policies.
content: The Federal Reserve chair, Jerome H. Powell, delivered a stark warning on Wednesday that the United States was experiencing an economic hit “without modern precedent,” one that could permanently damage the economy if Congress and the White House did not provide sufficient financial support to prevent a wave of bankruptcies and prolonged joblessness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kimmelman
title: When Manhattan Was Mannahatta: A Stroll Through the Centuries
description: From lush forest to metropolis, the evolution of Lower Manhattan. Our critic walks with Eric W. Sanderson of the Wildlife Conservation Society.
content: Before the first Dutch colonists sailed through the Narrows into New York Harbor, Manhattan was still what the Lenape, who had already lived here for centuries, called Mannahatta. Times Square was a forest with a beaver pond. The Jacob K. Javits Federal Building, at Foley Square, was the site of an ancient mound of oyster middens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Federal Retirement Fund Halts Planned China Investment Under Pressure
description: The change in plans for the $600 billion Thrift Savings Plan for federal workers comes as the Trump administration ramps up criticism of China.
content: WASHINGTON — A government retirement fund on Wednesday halted plans to invest in Chinese stocks this year, after growing criticism that the move would channel the savings of government workers to companies that are working against the national security goals of the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: Who Can Say ‘No’ to Cuomo? His Top Aide, Melissa DeRosa
description: Many unfamiliar with state politics have wondered about the steady, steely presence six feet from the governor’s elbow during his popular daily briefings. Here’s an introduction.
content: Competence is captivating. No need to tell viewers tuning in to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s daily media briefings. Many have been riveted by his plain talk in the face of a global pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Jill Lepore’s New Podcast Is a Murder Mystery: Who Killed Truth?
description: In “The Last Archive,” Lepore mixes history and 1930s-style radio drama to solve a timely whodunit.
content: In 1919, a woman was found dead in a park in a small town in Vermont. She had been bound and gagged and stripped naked except for her gray-blue stockings. Her glasses were caught in her hair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: In a First, Renewable Energy Is Poised to Eclipse Coal in U.S.
description: The coronavirus has pushed the coal industry to once-unthinkable lows, and the consequences for climate change are big.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States is on track to produce more electricity this year from renewable power than from coal for the first time on record, new government projections show, a transformation partly driven by the coronavirus pandemic, with profound implications in the fight against climate change.

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: ad hoc
description: This term has appeared in 168 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 13, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, May 13, 2020.
content: An article on Tuesday about the soccer player Andrés Iniesta misidentified the location of his childhood home. It is Albacete, Spain, not Asturias.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Here’s What the First Night of the Subway Shutdown Looked Like’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about the impact of shutting New York’s subway down overnight and reflect on ways to support transit workers, homeless people and daily subway riders.
content: Featured Article: “Here’s What the First Night of the Subway Shutdown Looked Like” by Christina Goldbaum
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: Wednesday’s Livestreaming Events: Padma Lakshmi, Connie Britton, Gabrielle Union and More
description: Appointment viewing is back. Find out what online events to look for today, and when to tune in.
content: Here are a few of the best events happening on Wednesday and how to tune in (all times are Eastern).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Kids Are Grieving, Too
description: Parents are facing difficult moments as children confront the death of a loved one, something they may not fully understand.
content: The coronavirus pandemic has taken more than a quarter of a million lives, many of them mothers, fathers, aunts, uncles and grandparents — adults who have left grieving children behind. Many more children will lose loved ones in the coming months. Here’s some guidance on how to talk to kids about illness and death, and how to support them when someone they love dies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Succeed at All of Life’s Endeavors
description: Benjamin Kramer returns to turn a page.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — When we last saw Benjamin Kramer in The New York Times Crossword, he was serving his puzzle to us over a net in a raucous game of volleyball. In this puzzle — and at a time when we are pursuing hobbies within our homes — he is settling us down with a much quieter activity.
source.name: The New York Times

title: An Eco-Friendly Estate in Nicaragua
description: This eco-friendly estate, set on about nine acres outside the popular surfing town of San Juan del Sur, Nicaragua, is available for $650,000.
content: This eco-friendly estate, set on about nine acres outside the popular surfing town of San Juan del Sur, Nicaragua, is available for $650,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: The Easiest, Crunchiest Baked Mac and Cheese
description: You don’t have to boil noodles or make a roux for this super easy version of the classic comfort food.
content: My tween daughter doesn’t miss going out to restaurants with the same urgent sting that my husband and I do. But she does miss us going out to eat — and leaving her with a cool teenage babysitter, the remote control and a big, gooey pan of baked mac and cheese.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: ad hoc
description: This term has appeared in 168 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: An Eco-Friendly Estate in Nicaragua
description: This eco-friendly estate, set on about nine acres outside the popular surfing town of San Juan del Sur, Nicaragua, is available for $650,000.

Many more children will lose loved ones in the coming months. Here’s some guidance on how to talk to kids about illness and death, and how to support them when someone they love dies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: This Isn’t Forever. But We Can Make It Better Now.
description: Tips on how to lead a more pleasurable, more cultured, happier life at home.
content: Welcome! It’s a funny feeling to think that it might not go on forever, the isolation and social distancing, the scary trips to the market, the fear of the half-masked bicyclist approaching on the footpath, the days spent working on that uncomfortable chair, the days spent not working and navigating bureaucracies in search of relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Utah Lowers Penalty for Polygamy, No Longer a Felony
description: An amendment that went into effect this week allows polygamy to be punished as an infraction in some cases, but it remains a felony if force, threats or other abuses are involved.
content: A new law that took effect in Utah this week has lowered the punishment for polygamy in some cases, making it an infraction similar to a traffic summons instead of a felony punishable by a prison term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: New Inflammatory Condition in Children Probably Linked to Coronavirus, Study Finds
description: Researchers compared 10 cases in Italy with previous cases of a similar childhood illness, Kawasaki disease. The rate of the new cases was much higher, and the conditions were more serious.
content: As concerns mount over children with a serious and potentially deadly inflammatory condition, a new study sheds light on the illness’s distinctive characteristics and provides the strongest evidence yet that the syndrome is linked to the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo and Emma Bubola
title: In Italy, Some Fear the Virus Is a Get-Out-of-Jail Card for Mafiosi
description: Hundreds of maximum-security inmates, including three mob bosses, were granted house arrest because of health concerns. The backlash forced the government to scramble.
content: ROME — They were among the most vulnerable as the coronavirus roared through Italy: older or riddled with serious underlying medical conditions. A brush with the virus within the confines of the place where they woke up each morning might seriously threaten their lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: Republican Wins House Seat in California Special Election
description: Mike Garcia, who won the endorsement of President Trump, flipped California’s 25th Congressional District after Representative Katie Hill, a Democrat, resigned last year.
content: LOS ANGELES — Mike Garcia, a former military pilot and newcomer to Republican electoral politics, has defeated his Democratic opponent in a special election to fill a House seat in Southern California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: David Chang Permanently Closes 2 of His Restaurants
description: The chef behind the Momofuku empire won’t reopen Nishi in New York and CCDC in Washington.
content: The prolific restaurateur David Chang told The New York Times Magazine in March, after restaurants closed across the nation, that without some serious government help, the industry would crumble.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Modern Love Podcast: Alone.
description: We wanted to know how those living alone during the coronavirus pandemic were faring in isolation. More than 2,000 people around the world responded.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: Officials Move to Block Concert Billed as First Since Virus Hit
description: Arkansas officials said they would not approve the planned Friday concert by Travis McCready as the promoters announced a second show in nearby Missouri.
content: Technically, the first major rock concert to open in the United States since the pandemic hit is still on for Friday. But its prospects were certainly clouded by an announcement Tuesday that the Arkansas Department of Health would issue a cease-and-desist order to block it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Guerrero
title: The Pandemic Work Diary of Netflix’s Queer Champion
description: “Joining the ranks of every other clichéd gay in L.A.,” Fran Tirado is writing scripts and monitoring the platform’s L.G.B.T.Q. content.
content: Fran Tirado is producing queer content and only queer content. “I’m just so uninterested in making anything that is not for queer-trans audiences,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nilo Tabrizy, Ainara Tiefenthäler and Noah Throop
title: Are Ice Cream Trucks Essential? In These N.Y.C. Neighborhoods, They Are
description: Godfrey Robinson has driven his ice cream truck along the same route for 26 years. Though his business is down, he’s out there, he says, to provide a sense of normalcy.
content: Godfrey Robinson has driven his ice cream truck along the same route for 26 years. Though his business is down, he’s out there, he says, to provide a sense of normalcy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Charges Against Former Michigan State President Are Dismissed
description: A judge said prosecutors had failed to prove that Lou Anna K. Simon knew of sexual abuse committed by Dr. Lawrence G. Nassar when he was employed by the university.
content: A judge on Wednesday dismissed a criminal case against Lou Anna K. Simon, the former Michigan State University president who was charged with lying to investigators about her knowledge of sexual abuse committed by Dr. Lawrence G. Nassar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Is This a Livestream I See Before Me?
description: All the world with an internet connection has suddenly become a stage. A lot of those stages have programmed Shakespeare.
content: On April 23, Shakespeare turned 456. Like many of us, he celebrated that birthday online.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Wisconsin Supreme Court Strikes Down Stay-at-Home Order
description: President Trump pushes to reopen schools, and criticizes Dr. Fauci’s warnings about moving too quickly. The administration weighs extending some border restrictions indefinitely.
content: The Wisconsin Supreme Court on Wednesday rejected the extension of the state’s stay-at-home order, siding with Republican legislators in a high-profile challenge of the emergency authority of a statewide official during the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Mike Storen, 84, Dies; Ran a Basketball League and Three Teams
description: He was commissioner of the upstart American Basketball Association and built the Indiana Pacers and the Kentucky Colonels into champions.
content: Mike Storen, a peripatetic sports executive who, during the brief life of the upstart American Basketball Association in the 1960s and ’70s, ran three teams and was the league’s commissioner, died on May 7 in Atlanta. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Anti-Lockdown Protesters Get in Reporters’ (Masked) Faces
description: Journalists covering the pandemic have faced the wrath of people who are against social-distancing restrictions.
content: For some reporters, the up-close wrath of anti-lockdown protesters has become a hazard of the job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Venezuelan Oil Company Sues Miami Ex-Congressman Over $50 Million Deal
description: Former Representative David Rivera, a strident anti-communist, was quietly consulting for President Nicolás Maduro’s socialist government. He produced five pages of reports, the lawsuit said.
content: MIAMI — Venezuela’s state-run oil company was on the verge of financial ruin in 2017 when it decided it needed expert advice on how to improve its reputation and standing with American policymakers who could be instrumental to its survival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: Get Ready for a Vaccine Information War
description: Social media is already filling up with misinformation about a Covid-19 vaccine, months or years before one even exists.
content: The other night, midway through watching a clip from “Plandemic” — a documentary that went viral on social media last week, spreading baseless lies and debunked nonsense about the coronavirus to millions of Americans overnight — I had a terrifying thought:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bradley Berman
title: Two New Cars, Designed From the Inside Out
description: Byton and Canoo offer radically distinct approaches to the way cars work for their owners. Canoo even does away with the idea of ownership.
content: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — In Silicon Valley, it’s not so unusual to get a sneak peek of tech products with revolutionary potential. On a Saturday afternoon early this year, eight beta testers gathered to experience a novel piece of electronic equipment: a digital screen embedded in the entire width of a car’s dashboard, from one pillar to the other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bradley Berman
title: Two New Cars, Designed From the Inside Out
description: Byton and Canoo offer radically distinct approaches to the way cars work for their owners. Canoo even does away with the idea of ownership.
content: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — In Silicon Valley, it’s not so unusual to get a sneak peek of tech products with revolutionary potential. On a Saturday afternoon early this year, eight beta testers gathered to experience a novel piece of electronic equipment: a digital screen embedded in the entire width of a car’s dashboard, from one pillar to the other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Pownall
title: The Blessing of Distraction
description: The comforting logic of sudoku puzzles offered respite from one woman’s tragedy.
content: I showed no external signs of physical distress during the first ectopic pregnancy. The metropolitan hospital was predictably busy, and despite being told that I was at risk of rupture, they used my place in the queue for other, more pressing patient cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Coronavirus, California, Michael Flynn: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: President Trump insists that things are looking up with the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What’s the Craziest Thing You Did as a Kid?
description: A 5-year-old boy is stopped by a trooper driving a car on the highway. What’s the wildest story from your childhood?
content: Have you ever done something in your childhood so wild, foolish, risky or crazy that today you still can’t believe it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: $2.2 Million Homes in California, the District of Columbia and New York
description: A midcentury-modern house in Pasadena, a rowhouse in Washington and a triplex apartment in Brooklyn.
content: John F. Galbraith, an architect who built in and around Pasadena, designed this house for a pharmacist and his family. The property is in North Kinneloa Ranch, a gated community named for the developer Abbot Kinney that was subdivided in the 1940s and has 41 houses. It is in the foothills of the San Gabriel Mountains, six miles northeast of the center of downtown Pasadena, with views of the Los Angeles Basin, and two miles northwest of shopping areas in the Hastings Ranch neighborhood. The owners have occupied the home since 1963.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Maggie Haberman
title: Kushner, Law Aside, Doesn’t Rule Out Delaying 2020 Election
description: The opinion of a White House staff member has no bearing on when the election is held, but his comment played into the concerns of President Trump’s detractors.
content: WASHINGTON — Jared Kushner, the president’s son-in-law and a senior White House adviser, refused on Tuesday to rule out postponing the presidential election in November, a comment that fed directly into Democratic concerns that President Trump might use the coronavirus crisis to delay or delegitimize the contest and one that contradicted Mr. Trump himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxana Popescu
title: House Hunting in Nicaragua: A Solar-Powered Ranch for $650,000
description: In the popular surf town of San Juan del Sur, the global pandemic is smothering market gains forged after Nicaragua’s political turmoil of 2018.
content: This eco-friendly equestrian estate is set on about nine acres outside the popular coastal town of San Juan del Sur, in southwestern Nicaragua.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 4 Writers to Watch This Summer
description: Brit Bennett, Megha Majumdar, Roddy Doyle and Marie-Helene Bertino talk about their new books.
content: Growing up in rural Palmetto, La., during Jim Crow, Lena Bennett used to sit with other black kids on the upper level of the segregated movie theater and throw popcorn kernels onto the heads of white people in the seats below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: Can the N.B.A. Come Back, and Stay Back?
description: In this week’s newsletter, Marc Stein looks at the health, safety and financial implications of the N.B.A. decision to restart or cancel the 2019-20 season.
content: Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Stein’s weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Willie Mays at 89: ‘My Thing Is Keep Talking and Keep Moving’
description: As the coronavirus pandemic keeps him homebound, the greatest living baseball player is missing visits to the ballpark, as well as opportunities to promote a new book on his life.
content: Baseball is almost like oxygen for Willie Mays. He spent a month this year with his old team, the San Francisco Giants, at spring training in Scottsdale, Ariz., where baseball’s greatest living player served as unofficial clubhouse greeter. In normal times, Mays would now be a regular presence at the Giants’ home games, sharing stories and laughs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Willie Mays at 89: ‘My Thing Is Keep Talking and Keep Moving’
description: As the coronavirus pandemic keeps him homebound, the greatest living baseball player is missing visits to the ballpark, as well as opportunities to promote a new book on his life.
content: Baseball is almost like oxygen for Willie Mays. He spent a month this year with his old team, the San Francisco Giants, at spring training in Scottsdale, Ariz., where baseball’s greatest living player served as unofficial clubhouse greeter. In normal times, Mays would now be a regular presence at the Giants’ home games, sharing stories and laughs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Schwartz
title: Michael Armstrong, Who Published a Local Brooklyn Paper, Dies at 79
description: Active in politics, he was best known as publisher of The Phoenix Newspaper. He and his wife, Dnynia Armstrong, 80, died of the coronavirus a month apart.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott
title: We Miss You, Cannes: 23 Filmmakers Relive Indelible Moments
description: Alejandro González Iñárritu, Clint Eastwood and other auteurs share memories from the film festival, like the rapturous boos and the police chief in love with movies.
content: There is nothing in the movie world that equals the glamour, artistic grandeur and occasional absurdity of the Cannes Film Festival, where stars and directors gather every May to be seen, celebrated and judged by the press and their peers. Over a frenzied week and half, oligarchpieces are unveiled and reputations are made. There are rapturous ovations and lusty boos. This year, because of the coronavirus pandemic, none of that is happening, but we just can’t quit it. So we spoke to filmmakers around the world about their memories of Cannes and their thoughts about the future of cinema. Here are edited excerpts:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura May Todd
title: The Making of Prada’s Most Iconic Bag
description: Informed by Italy’s rich tradition of leather work, the Galleria is assembled from 83 fastidiously crafted pieces.
content: When it debuted in 2007, Prada’s Galleria bag, a pared-back leather zip-top tote with rounded handles reminiscent of the medicine-style bags popular in the 1950s, already had the makings of a classic. A sober answer to the era’s flashy It-bags, its clean lines and functional design quickly made it a favorite among customers searching for a versatile accessory with a more timeless, cerebral feel. (Its cinematic appeal was further solidified in 2015, when the brand commissioned the American director and photographer Autumn de Wilde to create a series of surreal short films, later reprised in 2017, inspired by the bag.) As Prada prepares to enter a new era — in which Raf Simons will join Miuccia Prada as the company’s co-creative director — the Galleria will remain, its ongoing popularity a testament to the brand’s heritage. And, with many of Italy’s manufacturing businesses now operating once again and shops poised to reopen after being hard hit by the global pandemic, the leather artisans who create each iteration of the bag have recently been able to resume their craft.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariel Padilla
title: Former Veterans Affairs Doctor Is Charged With Sexual Abuse of Patients
description: The doctor, Jonathan Yates, worked at a hospital in West Virginia. He was accused of causing bodily injury to some veterans and abusive sexual contact while they were incapacitated, according to the federal indictment.
content: A former doctor at a Veterans Affairs hospital in West Virginia was charged on Tuesday with sexually abusing several male patients over the course of six months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcelle Sussman Fischler
title: As Summer Nears, the Hamptons Face a ‘Feeding Frenzy’
description: The rush for houses got an early start as people sought to avoid the coronavirus outbreak in New York City, though some deals have gotten tangled in new statewide rules on evictions.
content: The Hamptons summer rental season, which traditionally runs from Memorial Day to Labor Day, got off to an unusually early and frantic start this spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Louisa Marie Summer and Alex Marshall
title: Solo for Flute, Airport Terminal and One Listener
description: A lucky group of concertgoers experienced live music for the first time since lockdown, in a series of ultra-intimate recitals.
content: On Sunday afternoon, Patrick Stein walked into Terminal 1 at Stuttgart Airport, normally one of the busiest in southern Germany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Marcus Payadue
title: Texas, Vaccines, Tomatoes: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘There’s a Quiet All Over the World’
description: Cheryl Strayed talks with the poet Billy Collins about memorization, “picture language” and the power of collective silence.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Can I Get Coronavirus From Riding an Elevator?
description: When infected people use elevators, they probably do leave some of their germs behind. Wear a mask and wash hands to lower your risk.
content: For people who live or work in tall buildings, taking an elevator feels riskier in the time of coronavirus. Even if we can avoid riding the elevator with other people, are we still riding with the germs they left behind?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcelle Sussman Fischler
title: As Summer Nears, the Hamptons Face a ‘Feeding Frenzy’
description: The rush for houses got an early start as people sought to avoid the coronavirus outbreak in New York City, though some deals have gotten tangled in new statewide rules on evictions.
content: The Hamptons summer rental season, which traditionally runs from Memorial Day to Labor Day, got off to an unusually early and frantic start this spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron E. Carroll
title: Too Many States Are Flying Blind Into Reopening. Not Indiana.
description: The federal government doesn’t seem willing to mobilize, so states will have to do the heavy lifting.
content: INDIANAPOLIS — One of the most frustrating things about this pandemic is that we still don’t know how many people have been truly infected. We know how many people have tested positive, but that’s not the same thing, because limits in testing don’t give us a full picture. It would require a full statewide, random sample study to allow us to see what’s going on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: As Hunger Spreads With Pandemic, Government Takes Timid Steps
description: The Trump administration has taken some steps to address spreading hunger during the economic crisis, but it has shied away from expanding programs that could provide more immediate relief.
content: WASHINGTON — As hunger spreads across a locked-down nation, the Trump administration has balked at the simplest ways to feed the hardest hit, through expanding school meals programs and food-stamp benefits and waiving work requirements as unemployment reaches record levels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Ukraine Passes a Critical Anticorruption Bill
description: The Parliament approved a measure to stop insiders from siphoning aid money, but other forms of fraud persist.
content: MOSCOW — The Ukrainian government cleared an important anticorruption hurdle Wednesday when Parliament passed a bill preventing insiders from siphoning off international aid money through bank bailouts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Hong Kong virus cases, Indonesia’s wildlife markets, quarantine: Here’s what you need to know.
content: After 23 days without any locally transmitted coronavirus infections, Hong Kong reported two new cases on Wednesday. A third case recorded on the same day was imported from Pakistan, bringing the city’s total number of infections to 1,051.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Charlie Savage
title: Republicans Release Names of Obama-Era Officials in ‘Unmaskings’ That Revealed Flynn
description: The moves prompted accusations that President Trump’s allies were disclosing the information for his political benefit.
content: WASHINGTON — Republican senators on Wednesday released the names of some Obama administration officials who made requests during the presidential transition to see fuller versions of classified intelligence reports, immediately prompting accusations that President Trump’s allies were wielding the information for his political benefit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: PGA Tour Lays Out Plan to Restart
description: Officials will add coronavirus testing for players, caddies and support staff when the golf tour resumes in mid-June without live spectators.
content: With the goal of resuming tournament play next month in Texas, PGA Tour officials on Wednesday outlined safety procedures they intend to implement, including layers of coronavirus testing for players, caddies and support personnel. The tour’s plan would restrict the movement of players during events, which will be conducted without live spectators, and encourage golfers to isolate themselves from the public when off the golf course.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: For U.S. Open Tennis, Florida and California May Be Escape Hatches
description: As the public health crisis drags on, it becomes more difficult to see a path toward holding the tournament as originally planned.
content: After weeks of clinging to its hopes of holding the United States Open at its traditional New York home in front of fans, the United States Tennis Association has begun to seriously explore a series of alternative plans for the signature event that accounts for more than 80 percent of its revenue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Rogers
title: Missing the Acts You Love? Spare a Thought for These Superfans
description: Hard-core music, theater and movie aficionados from around the world told us how they’re coping in coronavirus lockdown.
content: Jiyoung Lee knows she’s an unlikely fan of BTS, the South Korean boy band. The seven-member K-pop group has attracted a passionate international following in recent years, selling out stadiums across Asia and the United States, largely to audiences in their teens or early 20s. Lee, on the other hand, is a 49-year-old professor at Sejong University specializing in the notoriously impenetrable work of the French philosopher Gilles Deleuze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Cohen
title: M.I.T. Closes ‘Food Computer’ Project After Scientists Raised Doubts
description: The OpenAg project, which promised crops that could be grown in thin air, faced scrutiny at the same time that Jeffrey Epstein’s financial ties to the M.I.T. Media Lab came to light.
content: A high-profile research project at M.I.T.’s Media Lab that promoted growing food at home in mini-greenhouses was quietly closed last month amid allegations that its results were exaggerated to sponsors and the public, the university confirmed this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: PGA Tour Lays Out Plan to Restart
description: Officials will add coronavirus testing for players, caddies and support staff when the golf tour resumes in mid-June without live spectators.
content: With the goal of resuming tournament play next month in Texas, PGA Tour officials on Wednesday outlined safety procedures they intend to implement, including layers of coronavirus testing for players, caddies and support personnel. The tour’s plan would restrict the movement of players during events, which will be conducted without live spectators, and encourage golfers to isolate themselves from the public when off the golf course.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gautier Billotte
title: T Process | Prada Galleria Bag
description: Artisans at the Scandicci factory near Florence, Italy, spend over six hours on each one of the iconic handbags.
content: Artisans at the Scandicci factory near Florence, Italy, spend over six hours on each one of the iconic handbags.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jillian Steinhauer
title: Five Artists to Follow on Instagram Now
description: Cultural hosts Lu Zhang and Herb Tam, “Corona Daze” poetry, printable exhibitions by Tiger Strikes Asteroid, Google street views.
content: I have a confession: I find looking at art on a computer to be generally unsatisfying. It’s no one’s fault, really, but digital images don’t capture the complexity of seeing a work in person, especially if it’s a three-dimensional object. The quality of my attention is different, too. Whereas I can spend several hours visiting galleries with only sporadic checks of my phone, I’m prone to refresh my email every five minutes while trying to view anything in a browser — especially now, when the pandemic has heightened my anxiety and distraction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manny Fernandez and David Montgomery
title: Businesses Chafing Under Covid-19 Lockdowns Turn to Armed Defiance
description: Armed militia-style protesters have helped businesses across Texas defy coronavirus lockdowns and reopen. Protesters say they are enforcing the Constitution.
content: SHEPHERD, Texas — When Jamie Williams decided to reopen her East Texas tattoo studio last week in defiance of the state’s coronavirus restrictions, she asked Philip Archibald for help. He showed up with his dog Zeus, his friends and his AR-15 semiautomatic rifle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Douglas W. Shadle
title: When the New York Philharmonic Fought Over Santa Claus
description: In the 19th century, a Christmas symphony became a flash point in the battle over the orchestra’s commitment to new American music.
content: The premieres of new works by Olga Neuwirth and Sarah Kirkland Snider were among the most crushing losses of the canceled final months of the New York Philharmonic’s season this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Joel Kupperman, Scarred by Success as a ‘Quiz Kid,’ Dies at 83
description: As a philosophy professor in adulthood, he would not speak of the World War II-era radio show (later on TV) that had made him famous and left him embittered.
content: They called him the midget Euclid, and baby Einstein. In 1944, The New York Times said he lisped in logarithms. For a time, during World War II and its aftermath, Joel Kupperman was one of the most famous children in the country, and also one of the most loathed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Tingley
title: Can ‘Team Science’ Yield a Covid-19 Treatment?
description: In just three months, international researchers found 30 existing drugs that seem to stop the coronavirus from destroying human cells.
content: Xin Yin was excited to be visiting his parents in the Shandong Province of China last December. Yin, a researcher in the Immunity and Pathogenesis Program at the Sanford Burnham Prebys Medical Discovery Institute in California, hadn’t been home in five years. So much had changed since then — a new high-speed rail station now connected his hometown with Beijing, for example. On Jan. 1, Yin was at the Beijing station, headed back to Shandong after seeing friends, when someone texted him about an unusual cluster of pneumonia cases in Wuhan. Pneumonia, an infection of the lungs, is typically caused by the flu or another virus. Yin, whose Ph.D. is in molecular virology, was intrigued. He texted a friend who lives in Wuhan, as well as several others who work in hospitals, to see if they had heard anything about the cluster. It wasn’t the flu, they told him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Coronavirus Wrecked Tesla’s Momentum and Elon Musk Is Furious
description: Mr. Musk opened his California factory this week in defiance of local orders. He has also criticized the response to the pandemic as “dumb” and “fascist.”
content: A few months ago, everything seemed to be going Elon Musk’s way, as he presided over an upstart electric car company that was worth more than General Motors, Ford Motor and Fiat Chrysler combined.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Judge Appoints Outsider to Take On Justice Dept. in Flynn Case
description: A retired judge will also examine whether the former national security adviser committed perjury.
content: WASHINGTON — The federal judge overseeing the case against President Trump’s former national security adviser Michael T. Flynn appointed a hard-charging former prosecutor and judge on Wednesday to oppose the Justice Department’s effort to drop the case and to explore a perjury charge against Mr. Flynn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Matt Damon Dishes About His Irish Lockdown in Radio Interview
description: In an interview with a Dublin radio station, the actor praised the people of Dalkey, the coastal town whose residents have adopted him as one of their own during the coronavirus epidemic.
content: Matt Damon has broken his silence about riding out the coronavirus lockdown in a seaside town in Ireland, dishing to a Dublin radio station about his newest FaceTime buddy (Bono) and what he was carrying in a SuperValu bag (beach towels) when he was spotted by locals.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: An Ecosystem Under Threat in Manhattan
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, May 13, 2020.
content: “It is not dramatic to say that we don’t know if Chinatown is going to be here when we come out of this.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘Ophelia’ and ‘Solar Opposites’
description: A spin on Shakespeare airs on Showtime. And a new animated sitcom with ties to “Rick and Morty” is on Hulu.
content: OPHELIA (2019) 10 p.m. on Showtime. The suggestion that Shakespeare wrote “King Lear” during plague lockdown has been widely circulated recently (online, at least), and some ambitious souls may be inspired to take advantage of social distancing to try to write the next great play, novel or TV pilot. For the rest of us, catching up on movies will have to suffice. One option, for those who missed it, is this revisionist take on “Hamlet.” As the title suggests, the movie takes the characters and plot of that Shakespeare play but gives them its own spin: It focuses on Ophelia (Daisy Ridley), the lover of Hamlet (George MacKay), who gets her own story line here as the action of the play takes a back seat. Directed by Claire McCarthy and based on a young adult novel by Lisa Klein, the movie makes for an “interesting exercise and, for the most part, a passably diverting one,” Manohla Dargis wrote in her review for The New York Times. This, Dargis added, is “Ophelia as a 21st-century heroine, who after a smudge-faced childhood running wild in her king’s castle — and being excluded from studying with the boys — grows into a woman with desires, ambitions and a pronounced rebellious streak.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: Is It Safe to Go Back to the Gym?
description: As gyms begin to reopen, many of us are wondering whether it’s safe, or wise, to return.
content: Is it safe to return to the gym? As a growing number of communities ease the stay-at-home mandates they had put in place to mitigate the spread of the novel coronavirus, gyms are beginning to reopen their doors — even as the virus continues to infect thousands more every day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Rosen
title: Helping the Environment, One Small Sensor at a Time
description: New York City nonprofits are using a cloud-based service from the start-up Temboo that helps monitor storm-water runoff and other environmental factors.
content: This article is part of our continuing Fast Forward series, which examines technological, economic, social and cultural shifts that happen as businesses evolve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: The Pandemic Will Permanently Change the Auto Industry
description: Plunging sales could force factories to close and lead to takeovers and mergers, but also bolster sales of electric cars.
content: FRANKFURT — Some automakers may emerge stronger, others too weak to survive on their own. Factories will shut down. The pressure to go electric could become more intense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Brian X. Chen
title: To Test or Not to Test?
description: Wednesday: As California gradually allows businesses to reopen, officials say there still isn’t enough testing to move more quickly.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Let Books Create Your Summer
description: This season’s reading will have to do more than usual to help us get away from it all while we can’t get away.
content: “The Daughter of Time” (1951), by the Scottish mystery writer Josephine Tey, begins with its detective laid up in the hospital with a broken leg, isolated and dispirited. But he pulls himself together. From his bed, he conducts a thrilling literary investigation into one of the great historical mysteries of the ages: whether Richard III really killed his nephews, the poor doomed princes in the tower. It’s a particularly satisfying response to an unexpected confinement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Ocasio-Cortez Commits Re-election Gaffe, Losing a Progressive Ballot Line
description: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez needed 15 signatures to secure a Working Families Party ballot spot, but a court challenge left her short of the mark.
content: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez is one of the best-known progressive politicians in the country, and her endorsement is sought by candidates running for president. Her firebrand style of politics has helped her raise millions of dollars and accumulate 6.9 million followers on Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabriel J.X. Dance and Lazaro Gamio
title: As Coronavirus Restrictions Lift, Millions in U.S. Are Leaving Home Again
description: Many states have moved to reopen businesses and public life, and the share of people sheltering in place has dropped, an analysis of cellphone location data shows.
content: Many states have moved to reopen businesses and public life, and the share of people sheltering in place has dropped, an analysis of cellphone location data shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Raftery
title: 12 Essential Lesser-Known Power-Pop Songs
description: You already listen to Cheap Trick, Big Star and the Raspberries. Now hear a dozen irresistibly upbeat tunes by smaller bands made between 1977 and 1983.
content: It was the summer of 1979, and parts of the world were in a state of near-surrender: In Britain, millions were reeling from the infamous “Winter of Discontent,” in which freezing temperatures and hot-tempered labor strikes left many people jobless, and some London streets buried in trash. Anxious Americans were fuming over the country’s second oil shortage in less than a decade, eventually prompting President Jimmy Carter to declare a nationwide “crisis of confidence.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: One Size Won’t Fit All for the Return of Sports
description: Cultural, political and financial factors will have some sports hustling back on the field, while others wait, and some cancel their seasons altogether.
content: You can move the Kentucky Derby to September from May. But you can’t expect horses to show up at Churchill Downs without some warm-up races.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juli Fraga and Hilary Jacobs Hendel
title: Questions for Your Prospective Therapist, From Your Own Couch
description: Even if you’re meeting online, interviewing a therapist can help you determine whether or not the therapy is a good fit.
content: From anxiety and loneliness to trauma and grief, the coronavirus pandemic is rattling our psychological well-being. According to a poll conducted in April by the Kaiser Family Foundation, 54 percent of women and 37 percent of men say the pandemic is worsening their mental health. Concerns about family members getting sick, economic instability and job loss were the survey respondents’ top worries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Todd Haugh and Suneal Bedi
title: Just Because You Test Positive for Antibodies Doesn’t Mean You Have Them
description: In a population whose infection rate is 5 percent, a test that is 90 percent accurate could deliver a false positive nearly 70 percent of the time.
content: Whether you think the country is reopening too fast or too slowly (or whether you think “it depends”), almost everyone agrees that testing should be critical to the next phase of our coronavirus existence. In particular, antibody tests that detect whether a person has developed immunity to the virus seem to offer a promising path forward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Running Your First Race Indoors
description: Here’s what life is like for a teacher who’s making her first run for office amid the pandemic.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: Low-Tech Way to Help Some Covid Patients: Flip Them Over
description: Turning ventilated patients onto their stomachs, called proning, helps them by opening their lungs. Now doctors are testing to see if it can keep others off ventilators altogether.
content: Hospitals across the country are filled with a curious sight these days: patients lying on their bellies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: The Metropolitan Opera Season That Vanished
description: Hear singers perform excerpts from productions that were canceled because of the coronavirus pandemic.
content: When the coronavirus shut the Metropolitan Opera’s doors on March 12, the company was hours away from bringing up the curtain on a revival of Rossini’s bubbly Cinderella adaptation, “La Cenerentola.” Massenet’s brooding “Werther” was to open a few days later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Burnt Out on Home Schooling?
description: How to get through the rest of the year.
content: There have been multiple pits of quicksand on our remote-learning journey, logistically and emotionally. One low point was the day my husband was on work calls from 9 a.m. until 7:45 p.m. in our bedroom. I was about to get on a video interview in my children’s bedroom when I yelled at them, “I don’t care what you do as long as you stay out of this room!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas
title: Coronavirus Testing Used by the White House Could Miss Infections
description: A study found that the Abbott ID Now machine was less accurate when it processed short, dry swabs.
content: A rapid coronavirus test used by the White House to screen its staff could miss infections up to 48 percent of the time, according to a study by researchers at N.Y.U. Langone Health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Eritreans Sue E.U. Over Use of Forced Labor Back Home
description: An Amsterdam-based group has filed a lawsuit against the European Union for funding an infrastructure project in Eritrea built by conscripts.
content: BRUSSELS — A Netherlands-based group of Eritreans sued the European Union on Wednesday, demanding it cease financing a project in the east African dictatorship that uses forced labor, the lawyer representing the group said, the first test of an effort by individuals and organizations to hold the bloc accountable for the way it spends billions in Africa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Paul Manafort, Trump’s Ex-Campaign Manager, Released to Home Confinement
description: Paul Manafort, who had been serving a seven-and-a-half-year sentence in Pennsylvania for fraud, is among the prisoners released over the spreading coronavirus.
content: WASHINGTON — Paul Manafort, President Trump’s former campaign chairman, was released from prison on Wednesday and granted confinement in his home in Northern Virginia because of the coronavirus pandemic, said one of his lawyers, Todd Blanche.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck, Lisa Lerer, Shane Goldmacher and Alexander Burns
title: Biden Has an Edge on Trump. So Why Are Democrats Worried?
description: The former vice president has unified the party and is leading in the polls. But some Democrats say he faces familiar challenges, including slow decision-making and flaws in his digital operation.
content: In his first weeks as the presumptive Democratic nominee, Joseph R. Biden Jr. went days at a time with no public events. His campaign staff in early April was about half the size of Hillary Clinton’s at the same time in 2016. A much-touted virtual rally last week was riddled with glitches. And Mr. Biden and his advisers remain stuck at home, uncertain if their Philadelphia headquarters will ever reopen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirk Semple
title: At Least 70 Dead in Mexico From Drinking Tainted Alcohol
description: The surge in deaths since late April has come amid the ban of alcohol sales by some local and state governments as part of efforts to control the coronavirus outbreak.
content: MEXICO CITY — At least 70 people have died across Mexico since late April after drinking tainted alcohol, including at least 20 residents of a poor mountain town in the central state Puebla who consumed a cheap, popular moonshine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitchell Abidor
title: These Young Socialists Think They Have Courage. They Don’t.
description: Many disappointed fans of Bernie Sanders would prefer a quixotic display of principle.
content: The progressive magazine The Nation published an open letter last month in which former members of the radical 1960s organization Students for a Democratic Society pleaded with a younger generation of leftists to support Joe Biden for president. The letter, titled “To the New New Left From the Old New Left,” warned that the re-election of President Trump would jeopardize “the very existence of American democracy.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus: The Risks of Reopening Too Soon
description: A reader, citing Dr. Anthony Fauci’s warning, says states are moving too quickly to reopen without taking the proper precautions. Also: Jared Kushner’s election remark; the World Trade Organization.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Investigating Tara Reade’s Accusation Against Joe Biden
description: Readers react to an Op-Ed writer’s reliance on philosophy to defend her decision to vote for Joe Biden even though she believes his accuser.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Raftery
title: 12 Essential Lesser-Known Power-Pop Songs
description: You already listen to Cheap Trick, Big Star and the Raspberries. Now hear a dozen irresistibly upbeat tunes by smaller bands made between 1977 and 1983.
content: It was the summer of 1979, and parts of the world were in a state of near-surrender: In Britain, millions were reeling from the infamous “Winter of Discontent,” in which freezing temperatures and hot-tempered labor strikes left many people jobless, and some London streets buried in trash. Anxious Americans were fuming over the country’s second oil shortage in less than a decade, eventually prompting President Jimmy Carter to declare a nationwide “crisis of confidence.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: One Size Won’t Fit All for the Return of Sports
description: Cultural, political and financial factors will have some sports hustling back on the field, while others wait, and some cancel their seasons altogether.
content: You can move the Kentucky Derby to September from May. But you can’t expect horses to show up at Churchill Downs without some warm-up races.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernie Tedeschi and Quoctrung Bui
title: America’s Employment Losses Might Be Slowing: Job Tracker
description: A new analysis of polling data suggests that the rapid rise in unemployment may be flattening, though not for everyone.
content: A new analysis of polling data suggests that the rapid rise in unemployment may be flattening, though not for everyone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Running Your First Race Indoors
description: Here’s what life is like for a teacher who’s making her first run for office amid the pandemic.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: Low-Tech Way to Help Some Covid Patients: Flip Them Over
description: Turning ventilated patients onto their stomachs, called proning, helps them by opening their lungs. Now doctors are testing to see if it can keep others off ventilators altogether.
content: Hospitals across the country are filled with a curious sight these days: patients lying on their bellies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Eritreans Sue E.U. Over Use of Forced Labor Back Home
description: An Amsterdam-based group has filed a lawsuit against the European Union for funding an infrastructure project in Eritrea built by conscripts.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Seems Ready to Curb ‘Faithless Electors’
description: Fearing chaos, several justices said states may require members of the Electoral College to vote for the presidential candidates they had promised to support.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court seemed ready on Wednesday to allow states to require members of the Electoral College to cast their votes for the presidential candidates they had pledged to support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Classes Canceled at Cal State Colleges, but Football May Not Follow
description: College officials have long maintained that athletes won’t play if students are kept off campus this fall because of the coronavirus. Now some sports leaders are hedging about the status of football.
content: In almost every corner of the college sports world — including the football playoff committee members speaking to Vice President Mike Pence — there has been a precise, unwavering benchmark  for football to return in the fall:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus ‘May Never Go Away,’ a Top W.H.O. Official Warns
description: Some countries are reinstating controls after backsliding. And a Canadian zoo may return its pandas to China, worried it can no longer find food for them.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Stocks Fall as Powell Warns of Lasting Economic Damage: Live Updates
description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
content: Stocks slid on Wednesday, Wall Street’s second drop in two days, after the chair of the Federal Reserve warned of dire consequences if lawmakers don’t do enough to protect the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck, Lisa Lerer, Shane Goldmacher and Alexander Burns
title: Biden Has an Edge on Trump. So Why Are Democrats Worried?
description: The former vice president has unified the party and is leading in the polls. But some Democrats say he faces familiar challenges, including slow decision-making and flaws in his digital operation.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger and Lara Jakes
title: On Annexation, a Green Light Turns Yellow, Pompeo’s Visit to Israel Signals
description: Although the secretary of state took pains to avoid publicly addressing the issue, he seemed to caution Israel’s leadership against moving too quickly to annex occupied territory.
content: JERUSALEM — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo’s eight-hour visit to Jerusalem on Wednesday for a lightning round of meetings with Israeli leaders raised one question that no one involved got around to answering:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman and Katie Benner
title: Ex-F.B.I. Official Is Said to Undercut Justice Dept. Effort to Drop Flynn Case
description: Prosecutors questioned a former F.B.I. official whose notes were used to buttress their motion to dismiss the charge against the president’s first national security adviser.
content: WASHINGTON — A key former F.B.I. official cast doubt on the Justice Department’s case for dropping a criminal charge against President Trump’s former national security adviser Michael T. Flynn during an interview with investigators last week, according to people familiar with the investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and David McCabe
title: Small-Business Loan Deadline Poses Test for Mnuchin
description: The Treasury Secretary has given big companies until May 18 to return their Paycheck Protection Program loans or face criminal liability. Many borrowers are rebuffing those demands.
content: WASHINGTON — When big businesses like Shake Shack and the Los Angeles Lakers basketball franchise took millions of dollars’ worth of emergency loans intended for small businesses, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin called such borrowing “outrageous,” narrowed eligibility and threatened to hold companies criminally liable if they did not give the money back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Jim Huylebroek
title: Born Into Carnage, 18 Afghan Babies Face an Uncertain Fate
description: A day after gunmen stormed a maternity ward and slaughtered new mothers at random, the authorities struggled to reconnect their children with families.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — When the carnage was over, the dead bodies bagged and the guns put away, what was left behind spoke of the true extent of the tragedy: 18 newborn babies, many covered in blood and most now motherless — casualties of war before they had even left the hospital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Don’t Get Dressed Without Watching This Show
description: “Mrs. America” is the fashion history lesson we all need.
content: We are all dressing for TV now — or at least for the small screen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Across Europe, Reopening Borders in Time for Summer
description: Countries across Europe, eyeing the summer holidays, are taking steps to begin reopening borders that had been closed to prevent the spread of coronavirus.
content: BERLIN — Europeans longing to swap their balconies for beaches, mountains or museums elsewhere on the continent got a morale boost on Wednesday, when the European Commission recommended the reopening of borders that were closed to stop the spread of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Senators Question Lower Relief Loan Amounts for Small Businesses
description: After learning that some received less than they asked for under the Paycheck Protection Program, three Democrats want more scrutiny of the banks.
content: Three Senate Democrats want Trump administration officials to keep a closer eye on the banks handing out aid to small businesses after some companies said they had received less than they expected, without explanation.
source.name: The New York Times
